content:
I started this PR (https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/1636) a bit ago, and I've been looking at the issues on and off over the last few days.

I think most of the errors are coming from a bunch of the instances of RelHomClass not being inferred (starting around line 188). I've tried debugging the best I can, but someone who understand this stuff better than I should probably take a look.

There are some totally unhelpful error messages like

type mismatch
  map_top
has type
  ‚àÄ (f : F), ‚Üëf ‚ä§ = ‚ä§ : Prop
but is expected to have type
  ‚àÄ (f : F), ‚Üëf ‚ä§ = ‚ä§ : Prop

where if I hover over any given sub-expression all the types match up.

This is one of the files in the direction of Data.Complex.Basic, but it doesn't have a lot of immediate descendants so it's not blocking all that much right now.

set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 2000
set_option trace.Meta.synthInstance true
-- See note [lower instance priority]
instance (priority := 100) BoundedLatticeHomClass.toBoundedOrderHomClass [Lattice Œ±] [Lattice Œ≤]
    [BoundedOrder Œ±] [BoundedOrder Œ≤] [BoundedLatticeHomClass F Œ± Œ≤] : BoundedOrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ :=
  let foo : OrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ := inferInstance
  sorry

gives

...
[resume] propagating (x_0 : Type _abstMVar.0) ‚Üí
        (x_1 : Type _abstMVar.1) ‚Üí
          (x_2 : Type _abstMVar.2) ‚Üí
            (x_3 : Type _abstMVar.3) ‚Üí
              (x_4 : Type _abstMVar.4) ‚Üí

                              (x_12 : Type _abstMVar.12) ‚Üí

                                    (x_15 : Type _abstMVar.15) ‚Üí

                                        (x_17 : Type _abstMVar.17) ‚Üí
                                          (x_18 : Type _abstMVar.18) ‚Üí
                                            Bot
                                              ((WithTop x_0)·µí·µà √ó
                                                (WithTop x_1)·µí·µà √ó

                                                                  (WithTop x_10)·µí·µà √ó

                                                                      (WithTop x_12)·µí·µà √ó

        (x_1 : Type _abstMVar.1) ‚Üí
          (x_2 : Type _abstMVar.2) ‚Üí
            (x_3 : Type _abstMVar.3) ‚Üí
...
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/slow.20.60positivity.60/near/322871598

Just telling Lean how to do it works:

instance (priority := 100) BoundedLatticeHomClass.toBoundedOrderHomClass [Lattice Œ±] [Lattice Œ≤]
    [BoundedOrder Œ±] [BoundedOrder Œ≤] [BoundedLatticeHomClass F Œ± Œ≤] : BoundedOrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ :=
{ show OrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ from SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass, ‚ÄπBoundedLatticeHomClass F Œ± Œ≤‚Ä∫ with }

This isn't going to end well either:

  [resume] propagating Lattice Œ± to subgoal Lattice Œ± of Lattice (WithTop Œ±) ‚ñ∂
  [resume] propagating Lattice (WithTop Œ±) to subgoal Lattice (WithTop Œ±) of Lattice (WithTop (WithTop Œ±)) ‚ñ∂
  [resume] propagating Lattice
        (WithTop (WithTop Œ±)) to subgoal Lattice (WithTop (WithTop Œ±)) of Lattice (WithTop (WithTop (WithTop Œ±))) ‚ñ∂
  [resume] propagating Lattice
        (WithTop
          (WithTop
            (WithTop
              Œ±))) to subgoal Lattice
        (WithTop (WithTop (WithTop Œ±))) of Lattice (WithTop (WithTop (WithTop (WithTop Œ±)))) ‚ñ∂
  [resume] propagating Lattice
        (WithTop
          (WithTop
            (WithTop
              (WithTop
                Œ±)))) to subgoal Lattice
        (WithTop (WithTop (WithTop (WithTop Œ±)))) of Lattice (WithTop (WithTop (WithTop (WithTop (WithTop Œ±))))) ‚ñ∂
  [resume] propagating Lattice

Here's the behaviour on master:

import Mathlib.Order.Hom.Basic

class SupHomClass (F : Type _) (Œ± Œ≤ : outParam <| Type _) [HasSup Œ±] [HasSup Œ≤] extends
  FunLike F Œ± fun _ => Œ≤ where
  map_sup (f : F) (a b : Œ±) : f (a ‚äî b) = f a ‚äî f b

class LatticeHomClass (F : Type _) (Œ± Œ≤ : outParam <| Type _) [Lattice Œ±] [Lattice Œ≤] extends
  SupHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ where
  map_inf (f : F) (a b : Œ±) : f (a ‚äì b) = f a ‚äì f b

class BoundedLatticeHomClass (F : Type _) (Œ± Œ≤ : outParam <| Type _) [Lattice Œ±] [Lattice Œ≤]
  [BoundedOrder Œ±] [BoundedOrder Œ≤] extends LatticeHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ where
  map_top (f : F) : f ‚ä§ = ‚ä§
  map_bot (f : F) : f ‚ä• = ‚ä•

instance (priority := 100) SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass [SemilatticeSup Œ±] [SemilatticeSup Œ≤]
    [SupHomClass F Œ± Œ≤] : OrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ :=
  { ‚ÄπSupHomClass F Œ± Œ≤‚Ä∫ with
    map_rel := fun f a b h => by rw [‚Üê sup_eq_right, ‚Üê map_sup, sup_eq_right.2 h] }

example [Lattice Œ±] [Lattice Œ≤] [BoundedOrder Œ±] [BoundedOrder Œ≤] [BoundedLatticeHomClass F Œ± Œ≤] :
    OrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ :=
SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass -- works

set_option synthInstance.maxHeartbeats 400 in -- to stop huge outputs crashing VS code
set_option trace.Meta.synthInstance true in
example [Lattice Œ±] [Lattice Œ≤] [BoundedOrder Œ±] [BoundedOrder Œ≤] [BoundedLatticeHomClass F Œ± Œ≤] :
    OrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ :=
inferInstance -- loops

People who understand these traces better than me can usually stare at the output below and instantly go "it went wrong at precisely this point and that's your bad instance".

  [] new goal RelHomClass F _tc.2 _tc.3 ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass to RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1 ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeSup to SemilatticeSup (WithTop ?m.2939) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply Prod.semilatticeSup to SemilatticeSup (?m.2943 √ó ?m.2944) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeSup to SemilatticeSup (WithTop ?m.2956) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply Prod.semilatticeSup to SemilatticeSup (?m.2960 √ó ?m.2961) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply OrderDual.semilatticeSup to SemilatticeSup ?m.2965·µí·µà ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeInf to SemilatticeInf (WithTop ?m.2976) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply Prod.semilatticeInf to SemilatticeInf (?m.2980 √ó ?m.2981) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply OrderDual.semilatticeInf to SemilatticeInf ?m.2985·µí·µà ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithBot.semilatticeInf to SemilatticeInf (WithBot ?m.2988) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @Pi.semilatticeInf to SemilatticeInf ((i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí ?m.2992 i) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (WithTop (?m.3006 i)) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply Prod.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (?m.3015 i √ó ?m.3016 i) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply OrderDual.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (?m.3025 i)·µí·µà ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (WithTop (?m.3042 i)) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply Prod.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (?m.3051 i √ó ?m.3052 i) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply OrderDual.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (?m.3061 i)·µí·µà ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithBot.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (WithBot (?m.3069 i)) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @Pi.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup ((i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí ?m.3078 i i_1) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (WithTop (?m.3098 i i_1)) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply Prod.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (?m.3112 i i_1 √ó ?m.3113 i i_1) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply OrderDual.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (?m.3127 i i_1)·µí·µà ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (WithTop (?m.3150 i i_1)) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply Prod.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (?m.3164 i i_1 √ó ?m.3165 i i_1) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply OrderDual.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (?m.3179 i i_1)·µí·µà ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithBot.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (WithBot (?m.3192 i i_1)) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @Pi.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí
        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf ((i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí ?m.3206 i i_1 i_2) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí
        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí (i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (WithTop (?m.3232 i i_1 i_2)) ‚ñ∂

        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí (i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (?m.3251 i i_1 i_2 √ó ?m.3252 i i_1 i_2) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply OrderDual.semilatticeInf to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí
        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí (i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí SemilatticeInf (?m.3271 i i_1 i_2)·µí·µà ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí
        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí (i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (WithTop (?m.3300 i i_1 i_2)) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply Prod.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí
        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí (i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (?m.3319 i i_1 i_2 √ó ?m.3320 i i_1 i_2) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply OrderDual.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí
        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí (i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (?m.3339 i i_1 i_2)·µí·µà ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithBot.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí
        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí (i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (WithBot (?m.3357 i i_1 i_2)) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @Pi.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí
        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí (i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup ((i_3 : ?m.3375 i i_1 i_2) ‚Üí ?m.3376 i i_1 i_2 i_3) ‚ñ∂
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeSup to (i : ?m.2991) ‚Üí
        (i_1 : ?m.3077 i) ‚Üí
          (i_2 : ?m.3205 i i_1) ‚Üí (i_3 : ?m.3375 i i_1 i_2) ‚Üí SemilatticeSup (WithTop (?m.3408 i i_1 i_2 i_3)) ‚ñ∂
@Mario Carneiro you're one of those people ;-)

Is it this?

[Meta.synthInstance] üí• RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1 ‚ñº
  [] new goal RelHomClass F _tc.2 _tc.3 ‚ñº
    [instances] #[@OrderIsoClass.toOrderHomClass, @SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass]
  [] ‚úÖ apply @SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass to RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1 ‚ñº
    [tryResolve] ‚úÖ RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1 ‚âü RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1
    [] new goal SemilatticeSup _tc.0 ‚ñº
      [instances] #[@Lattice.toSemilatticeSup, @Pi.semilatticeSup, @WithBot.semilatticeSup, OrderDual.semilatticeSup, Prod.semilatticeSup, @WithTop.semilatticeSup]
  [] ‚úÖ apply @WithTop.semilatticeSup to SemilatticeSup (WithTop ?m.2939) ‚ñº
    [tryResolve] ‚úÖ SemilatticeSup (WithTop ?m.2939) ‚âü SemilatticeSup (WithTop ?m.2939)

/-- `RelHomClass F r s` asserts that `F` is a type of functions such that all `f : F`
satisfy `r a b ‚Üí s (f a) (f b)`.

The relations `r` and `s` are `outParam`s since figuring them out from a goal is a higher-order
matching problem that Lean usually can't do unaided.
-/
class RelHomClass (F : Type _) {Œ± Œ≤ : outParam <| Type _} (r : outParam <| Œ± ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí Prop)
  (s : outParam <| Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ≤ ‚Üí Prop) extends FunLike F Œ± fun _ => Œ≤ where
  /-- A `RelHomClass` sends related elements to related elements -/
  map_rel : ‚àÄ (f : F) {a b}, r a b ‚Üí s (f a) (f b)
It looks like the SemilatticeSup Œ± goal in SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass is not being treated like an out-param

@SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass : {Œ± : Type u_1} ‚Üí
  {Œ≤ : Type u_2} ‚Üí
    {F : Type u_3} ‚Üí
      [inst : SemilatticeSup Œ±] ‚Üí [inst_1 : SemilatticeSup Œ≤] ‚Üí [inst_2 : SupHomClass F Œ± Œ≤] ‚Üí OrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤

No mention of outparams there
it looks like lean4#1852
Can you explain more precisely what this means? I only have the vaguest concept of what an out-param is.
this is all to do with when...unification?...tries to fill in a hole?

Specifically, we have the goal OrderHomClass F ?Œ± ?Œ≤ (where ?Œ±, ?Œ≤ are forcibly made into metavariables because they are outparams) and want to find a solution to the typeclass problem which will determine ?Œ±, ?Œ≤
SemilatticeSup Œ± does not have Œ± as an outparam, so it would be a bad idea to do a typeclass search for SemilatticeSup ?Œ± immediately, because that will enumerate all semilattices
which it's doing, right?
right

instance (priority := 100) SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass [outparam (SemilatticeSup Œ±)] [SemilatticeSup Œ≤]
    [SupHomClass F Œ± Œ≤] : OrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ :=
  { ‚ÄπSupHomClass F Œ± Œ≤‚Ä∫ with
    map_rel := fun f a b h => by rw [‚Üê sup_eq_right, ‚Üê map_sup, sup_eq_right.2 h] }
/-
invalid binder annotation, type is not a class instance
  ?m.1448
use the command `set_option checkBinderAnnotations false` to disable the check
-/

The correct order of evaluation here is:

  1. SupHomClass F ?Œ± ?Œ≤, which solves ?Œ± := Œ± and ?Œ≤ := Œ≤
  2. SemilatticeSup Œ±
  3. SemilatticeSup Œ≤
you misspelled outParam
it would be great if that worked, if only as a workaround, but I think that outparam annotations are ignored on instances

instance (priority := 100) SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass  {Œ± Œ≤ : outParam <| Type _} [outParam (SemilatticeSup Œ±)] [outParam (SemilatticeSup Œ≤)]
    [outParam (SupHomClass F Œ± Œ≤)] : OrderHomClass F Œ± Œ≤ :=
  { ‚ÄπSupHomClass F Œ± Œ≤‚Ä∫ with
    map_rel := fun f a b h => by rw [‚Üê sup_eq_right, ‚Üê map_sup, sup_eq_right.2 h] }

This doesn't fix it
Gabriel's workaround is to use {_ : SemilatticeSup Œ±} in the instance, but I think that won't work here because SupHomClass requires HasSup instead of SemilatticeSup

I don't understand why this is happening

[Meta.synthInstance] üí• RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1 ‚ñº
  [] new goal RelHomClass F _tc.2 _tc.3 ‚ñº
    [instances] #[@OrderIsoClass.toOrderHomClass, @SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass]
  [] ‚úÖ apply @SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass to RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1 ‚ñº
    [tryResolve] ‚úÖ RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1 ‚âü RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1
    [] new goal outParam (SemilatticeSup _tc.0) ‚ñº
      [instances] #[@Lattice.toSemilatticeSup, @Pi.semilatticeSup, @WithBot.semilatticeSup, OrderDual.semilatticeSup, Prod.semilatticeSup, @WithTop.semilatticeSup]

when we have this

RelHomClass : Type u_1 ‚Üí
  {Œ± : outParam (Type u_2)} ‚Üí
    {Œ≤ : outParam (Type u_3)} ‚Üí outParam (Œ± ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí Prop) ‚Üí outParam (Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ≤ ‚Üí Prop) ‚Üí Type (max (max u_1 u_2) u_3)

Oh! The outParam falls off in this trace:

[Meta.synthInstance] üí• RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1 ‚ñº
  [] new goal RelHomClass F _tc.2 _tc.3 ‚ñº
    [instances] #[@OrderIsoClass.toOrderHomClass, @SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass]
  [] ‚úÖ apply @SupHomClass.toOrderHomClass to RelHomClass F (fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1) fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1 ‚ñº

The new goal was outParam (SemilatticeSup _tc.0) and then it became SemilatticeSup _tc.0
outParam isn't really a tag on goals, it's a tag on arguments to a typeclass
when it shows up elsewhere it's just a thing to be unfolded

What needs to be changed to make type class inference not try to solve SemilatticeSup _tc.0? Is this something which can be fixed in mathlib or does it need a change in core Lean? Do we need a new meme?
